body: Oh and the local state is messed up too. There are ~ 1TB of things in that folder, not 7 TB. It seems like the metadata counter gains a new "copy" of the local files whenever this happens.

I added some debugging and all the corrections are here:

https://github.com/calmh/syncthing/blob/2373a9272731a2e5328d299f627673cb15343354/lib/db/lowlevel.go#L890

("dropping incorrect sequence entry "Marketing/Fonts/IdealSans.zip" with wrong sequence (12753 != 12989)")

indicating that we're leaving old sequence entries around for some reason...

issue.title: Suppress "dir not empty" pull errors caused by errors on children

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New features or improvements of some kind, as opposed to a problem (bug)

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

issue.body:
To see whether I am also affected by #6614 I checked my homeserver ("unfortunately" not affected) and found this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15955093/81391899-28561d00-911e-11ea-8464-027b9ea59f5a.png)

The "not empty" errors are caused by the "contains ignored files" error. As they will go away when the child errors go away we should just suppress them, guiding the user to the relevant issue instead of potentially confusing them.  
A potential extension not specific to this error combination would be to suppress all parent errors and only track "leaf" errors (would require some thought whether that's always correct, as I'd rather display too much than too little information).

body: So the reason we're not dropping old sequence keys *and* the reason it's rescanning is because getting a file returns "nope, no such file" (so no old sequence key to delete), in turn because the indirected *block list* for that file is myseriously missing...
Let's not do ref counting, let's do gc they said, it will be great they said.
Uh huh. I'm having a serious discussion about responsibility with the gcRunner right now.
that's the only way indirect block lists can disappear, right? (other than not being written at all)
I hope so.
I guess returning not found is probably not helping detect this, it's probably wise to return some more specific error in this case as it's an unexpected consistency issue.

So the one advantage to doing it this way is that apart from causing havoc it's self repairing in the long run... But we should probably at the very least yell warnings as this is something that should never happen in production.

```
[SYNO4] 2020/05/08 11:40:43.136499 lowlevel.go:599: INFO: gc: new bloom filter with capacity 100000
[SYNO4] 2020/05/08 11:40:43.136600 lowlevel.go:609: INFO: gc: iterating files
[SYNO4] 2020/05/08 11:40:43.300000 lowlevel.go:636: INFO: gc: added 230322 block entries to filter, skipped 0 empty ones
[SYNO4] 2020/05/08 11:40:43.300014 lowlevel.go:641: INFO: gc: iterating block lists
[SYNO4] 2020/05/08 11:40:43.516113 lowlevel.go:669: INFO: gc: matched 400 block lists, dropped 60874 unused ones
```

ðŸ™„
LOL
The whole block list map stuff in my other PR could be folded into the blocklist (filenames in the list) and we could move to refcounting.
We don't need refcounting (imho), we just need a bloom filter that doesn't lie...
Sure, what I am saying is that I am already adding refcounting in my PR, so we might as well do it here, and not need a gc.
Then we'd have blocklist that also acts as a "which files have this hash"
Right, right. This one is anyway easily fixable as is.
Right now this is potential hot-fix release stuff, for which just fixing bloom is more suitable. Definitely need to check that PR though anyway, forgot about revisiting that (sorry).
We're cool on this, we don't have a release yet out with the bloom filter change. It's just me being bleeding edge. But yeah, I'll rather do that revert than bigger changes right now.

It's not even that, it's just a mistake in using the changed bloom filter:

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/commit/44b0f0b4#diff-e4dc421e8157ba4e8ba69c47a592dd10R650

it tests for the existence of something other than we add, as the BlocksHash() thing gets applied twice.
:frowning: Sorry about that.
